values: Sponsored by Common Media & Acquia, facilitated by Kelly Albrecht

This room will alternate, in ~30 minute windows of each, between two activities between Lean Coffee and Networking icebreakers.

Networking

As people join, we will use Zoom breakout rooms to pair up in various ways discussing icebreakers and generating topics for deeper discussion.

Lean Coffee

Lean Coffee is a structured, but agenda-less meeting. Participants gather, build an agenda, and begin talking. Conversations are directed and productive because the agenda for the meeting was democratically generated.

We will take our generated topics of interest, load them onto a virtual board, vote on them, and discuss in priority order together as a group.
Please attend the welcome session for information and orientation about today's schedule.

Many developers hear the word "accessibility" and are confused, intimidated, or don't have the time to fully explore how it applies to their work. In this session we will present how developing anything with accessibility in mind ensures that wider audiences are reached and no one is left out. The goal of this session is an introduction to web accessibility including how people with different disabilities access technology and how to remove basic stumbling blocks to ensure access for everyone.

Speaker notes:

I have presented about accessibility starting in 2017 with the UMass ICT conference. I have spoken at Accessibility conferences at Cornell University, UMass and UConn, including regular sessions at UMass through Workplace Learning and Development. I have also done virtual presentations with Tech Foundry on accessibility.

I will be presenting this session with an Undergraduate student at UMass who has a focus on Disability Studies.
CANCELLED <strike>Journey to Jira in the Cloud</strike>

Explore what Jira Cloud offers and touch on the migration from Jira Server or Jira Data Center. We expanded our Jira user base beyond developers and into the business. It was met with challenges and successes we couldn't have imagined.

More from the speaker:

I'm a project Manager, Agile Coach, Atlassian Administrator and InfoSec Evangelist. I've worked for Fortune 500 companies and very small startups and a few companies in between. My loves are learning, collaborating and my family, in no particular order.

I've been a speaker in my companies internal unconference. I'm a relative newbie speaking outside my employer's walls.

Your Google Reflection: Take control over your Google image.

Google controls 90% of the search market. It is probably how half your web visitors find and perhaps even navigate your website.

Together we will gaze into the Google magic mirror and see your website.

We'll look at the Google Search Engine Results Page (SERP), Google Search Console and Google My business and see what is going on over at google.com.

We will look at what Googlebot, Google's web crawler, thinks of your site. We'll find out what search terms people are using in Google Search, what your top search content is, and even see analytics on how often people use Google to get directions. If you have not done any of this before, you are guaranteed to learn something practical which will empower you to improve your search presence and help you with your SEO.

About the speaker:

Dave Ruderman is a software engineer and web developer at UMass Amherst. He has a minor history of being ahead of the curve - helping scientists with the human genome project before 23 and Me, doing search engine optimization (SEO) before Google, creating streaming video user interfaces before Netflix, and writing phone apps before the iPhone.

There's so much more to Slack than just sending text messages back and forth with your coworkers. In my talk, I'll demo some cool slack integrations and other tips and tricks, such as setting reminders, customizing slackbot messages, adding your own emojis, creating custom workflows, and more. I'll also provide some tips for administering slack - roles and permissions, changing the theme, setting up channels, etc. Finally, I'll show you how to find slack workspaces to join, and will share some of my favorites with you.

About the speaker:

VP of Digital Strategy, Isovera

At Isovera, I work with both clients and internal teams to identify unmet needs, goals, opportunities, and challenges, and provide clear roadmaps to solve for those issues.

In previous roles, I have contributed as a producer, designer, developer, writer, and project manager; this varied background helps me strategize on projects from all perspectives. I love that Isovera offers me the opportunity to work with bright, enthusiastic people who love technology as much as I do.

I presented at NERD Summit 2019 (and had a fantastic time!).

I also presented at NED Camp 2018 and led a BOF in 2020
When a The Sh** Hits the fan Volume 2 -- bigger, badder, now with Drupal 9 included

Two Drupal veterans share tips on how to rescue your Drupal Site when things go wrong. This is updated version of the presentation they did several years ago. Ally and Lanette each have spent over 7 years supporting some of the largest Drupal websites out there. We will talk about what to do prior to having a problem. Common types of Issue your will see. We will provide tips to quickly diagnose and fix issues.

Puppeteer is a Node library which provides a high-level API to control headless Chrome or Chromium over the DevTools Protocol. Puppeteer allows access to the measurement of loading and rendering times provided by the Chrome Performance Analysis tool. The most common use for this tool is testing as a replacement for Selenium. In this project, the audience a insights into creative use for this tool which should inspire them.
CANCELLED <strike>Time is an illusion (and getTime() doubly so)</strike>

In building a "simple" tea timer app in vanilla JavaScript, I discovered that timing isn't so simple -- especially not on the frontend. In addition to the challenges of building a JS app without a library, I also discovered that how the user perceives time passing is more interesting -- and more difficult -- than simply measuring the seconds.

Attendees will come away with an understanding of the depth of the problem of time in JS, and with some resources to build a timing app of their own.

Speaker Notes:

The original blog post: TIL in JavaScript timers

The tea timer in question: Teamer

Lise is a senior frontend engineer at Fishtown Analytics, the makers of dbt. She's passionate about solving gnarly problems, teaching coding, and explaining technical topics to a non-technical audience. When she's not working, she pretends to be a druid.
Plenti: A Svelte Static Site Generator with No Dependencies

JavaScript is more essential to the web today than ever before, but supporting a complex toolchain can get in your way and make you less productive.

Plenti (https://github.com/plentico/plenti) takes a new approach to building JS apps by cutting out the bundlers, hitting the compiler directly in V8, and building scaffolding in Go to give an extremely fast and consistent developer experience. It uses Svelte templates on the frontend so you get a reactive component architecture that's lightweight and fast. The build process runs very quickly so you get real-time updates and you don't need any tools or configuration to get started - NodeJS and NPM are optional.

In this talk, Jim, the primary developer for the project, will walk through the architecture choices and explain how Plenti works at a high level. Then he'll discuss plans for future releases and take questions / feedback from the group.

About the speaker:

Jim Fisk is a Framingham based web developer and the creator of Plentico. He started the JAMstack Boston meetup in 2017 where he has enjoyed teaching workshops on topics such as Hugo and NetlifyCMS while learning from others about new tools that make up this rapidly evolving ecosystem. He has led production builds using a variety of JAMstack technology, including Jekyll to build budget.boston.gov and Gatsby to create theiagroupinc.com. Jim is passionate about lowering barriers for new folks learning tech and founded a company called Jantcu LLC in 2015 that's focused entirely on free and open source software.
Advanced Group & Media Functionality on a Drupal8 site

In this session, we'll demonstrate how we have utilized advanced capabilities of Groups and Media in Drupal8 to build the GreatAlbum site.

Some key features we'll review include:

  • Sending invites to non-site users via email and having them accept/register
  • Making media entities part of group content
  • Group view includes a stream of content/media
  • Group tabs, so show streams for each content type
  • Group Activities document creation and updates of content/media in the group
  • Google Photos integration - create media entities in the group based on Google Photo Albums
  • Enabling content/media to belong to more than one Group
  • View all your content/media across Groups

      • About the speaker:

      Erik is a Business Development Executive for the last 10+ years, responsible for partner ecosystems of up to $1B. With GreatAlbum, he's acting out a 20 year old dream to build a website/app that enables people to collaboratively build and share rich stories about the family and friends that inspire them! He is the Founder, leading a small development team.
Is it flat? Organizational agility from the trenches.

Anyone who's worked in a small business knows how central the customer is to its success. As an organization grows larger, so do its needs for structural stability, yet customer centricity becomes no less important. As we continuously add structure to our organizations, building our corporate hierarchies, it becomes increasingly challenging to see the customer in the center or, in most cases, in the picture at all. How do we grow and stay stable as an organization while retaining our ability to nimbly adapt as our customers' needs change over time?

More from the speaker

My primary passion and motivation is in delivering better products by getting production teams and customers closer together through automation and empathy. I aspire to apply my skills and past successes in leadership strategy and management innovation to larger and larger organizations.

In late 2020 the Boston-Based designer and educator Dan Vlahos Design began collaborating with the Greenfield-based digital studio Facta to redesign Vlahos' website before his tenure case is submitted at Merrimack College—while also exploring several "bigger" conceptual questions. The site is currently in the stage of final editing.

Could a site that is designed to showcase "ideas" (projects, wiring, research, etc) use cues from the design of retail and editorial websites? Could "non-traditional" tools (from editorial design etc) be used to design it? Could the site be designed in such a way that its general frameworks could be opened up for others to use?

In 2019 Jessica Ivins published "An Essential Tool for Capturing Your Career Accomplishments" on A List Apart in which she describes a "Career Management Document (CMD) [as] a comprehensive collection of your résumé and portfolio content." With our project we dig even deeper into the issues identified by Ivins while attempting to bring to life through dynamic media.
Sponsored by Common Media & Acquia, facilitated by Kelly Albrecht
KEYNOTE : Ethan Zuckerman - What Went Wrong With the Web, and Who's Working to Make it Better

Over the past few years, enthusiasm about the transformations brought about by the internet has become tempered by concerns. Are we becoming addicted to mobile phones and social media? Is the internet making our politics more angry and our nation more divided? We'll examine the complexity of these questions and at a new wave of efforts designed to correct some of the problems that have emerged as the Web heads towards middle age.

About the speaker:

Ethan Zuckerman is associate professor of public policy, information and communication at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and director of the Institute for Digital Public Infrastructure. His research focuses on the use of media as a tool for social change, the use of new media technologies by activists and alternative business and governance models for the internet. He is the author of Mistrust: How Losing Trust in Institutions Provides Tools to Transform Them (2020) and Rewire: Digital Cosmopolitans in the Age of Connection (2013). With Rebecca MacKinnon, Zuckerman co-founded the international blogging community Global Voices. It showcases news and opinions from citizen media in more than 150 nations and 30 languages, publishing editions in 20 languages. Previously, Zuckerman directed the Center for Civic Media at MIT and taught at the MIT Media Lab. In 2000, Zuckerman founded Geekcorps, a technology volunteer organization that sends IT specialists to work on projects in developing nations, with a focus on West Africa. Previously, he helped found Tripod.com, one of the web's first "personal publishing" sites. He and his family live in Berkshire County in western Massachusetts.

Information Architecture may mean different things to different people. Let's get on the same page to better work together.

One of the most common user complaints we hear: "I cannot find what I'm looking for."

We will review how to create a more effective design and improved user experience. First we seek to understand the user, content, and context, then we begin to define our IA. How? We ask thoughtful questions and assessing value to those questions. Once we develop a functional understanding, we conduct research, facilitate exercises, and create guiding artifacts. This is not a one-size-fits-all approach. Instead, we will work adaptively to be more strategic.

Accessibility is essential for marketers that want to create high-quality content and not exclude people from using their products and services. If you're in charge of your team's marketing, you have a lot of things to cover between keeping it up to date, entering and managing content, and making sure it's all accessible.

As part of an inclusive content strategy, how accessible is your social media?

We'll do a deep dive into making your social media more accessible and in turn more inclusive. We'll cover definitions, standards, guidelines, as well as newsletters, social media copy, images, hashtags and more.

About the speaker:

AmyJune is an active contributor in the open-source world. As the Open Source Community Ambassador at Kanopi Studios, with a dual focus on both open-source community development and inclusivity, she is uniquely positioned to help individuals become more comfortable and confident as they contribute to their communities.

Her ongoing experience as a hospice nurse keeps her in touch with the challenges faced by many end-users. In her continued efforts to make a difference, she helps organize A11yTalks, an online meetup where they invite folks on every month to talk about all things accessibility - one of the core components of building an inclusive web.

In addition to her work building community connections, AmyJune is an avid geocacher, noted Volkswagen enthusiast, and eats with her elbows on the table.

The Raspberry Pi is a project-based single board computer. What? My brother-in-law said to me one Christmas when I received a new Pi 3 as a gift, "I love the idea of the Pi, but I have no idea what to do with it". This session introduces the Raspberry Pi and answers common questions:

  • What is a Pi?
  • What can I use it for?
  • How much will it cost?
  • Where do I start?
  • What should I purchase?

This is your Raspberry Pi 101.

More from the speaker:

I'm a web developer for 25+ year. Drupal developer, podcaster and Linux enthusiast.
Not your typical flip to Zoom

In mid-March 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic forced WISE, a lifelong learning program for seniors in the Worcester MA area, to cancel its classes. By April, WISE had scheduled more than two dozen class sessions. Then it was summer, nine courses for a total of 40 sessions. In the fall, 30 courses, five sessions each. WISE has more than 300 members, median age in the mid-70s. One-quarter of the members attend classes using mobile devices.

Karl Hakkarainen is a retired IT professional. He is technology adviser for Worcester Institute for Senior Education, a lifelong learning program at Assumption University. Karl has given talks at previous NERD Summits on agile documentation development, end-user support, and digital humanities. His grandchildren still ask him for help with their technical stuff.

As developers, we rely on having a development environment that allows us to seamlessly translate our ideas into code as quickly and efficiently as possible.

Some solutions, like PhpStorm, try and include everything and the kitchen sink within a single application. Other applications, like VS Code, try and approach the problem from the perspective of a souped-up text editor.
Jackpot!  A Look Inside a Virtual Pinball Machine

The game of pinball has been around for about 100 years, but only in the last decade or two have computers and software gotten to the point where they can provide the complete arcade experience. What's best is that because it's all virtual, one box can emulate hundreds of different physical machines, many of which would otherwise be difficult or impossible to find.

This talk will give you an in-depth view of one maker's own virtual pinball machine, complete with three video screens, flashing lights, and solenoids to emulate the sounds make by flippers, slingshots, and pop-bumpers. You'll also get a description of all the free and open source software that it runs.

Notes from the Speaker:

If I'm not at my day job, programming for Amherst College, I'm probably playing pinball, working on pinball machines, or fixing some part of our home automation system.

I envision this presentation as primarily a 25-30 minute pre-recorded video showing off the machine (hardware, software and gameplay), with time for Q&A afterward. If technically feasible, I'd like to do the Q&A in front of the actual machine in my home.

While I have not spoken at NERD Summit previously, I have presented technical topics at various other conferences, and am comfortable in front of crowds.
Non-Technical Founder's Approach to Agile Project Mgmt

Are you a non-technical Founder or Project Manager wondering how best to define the requirements and manage the development of a website or app? Attend this session to learn how one such non-technical Founder went about it - mistakes made, lessons learned, approach now being followed. A few highlights of the session:

  • Started Backlog.com - tried to manage requirements & tasks in a simple issue tracker, discovered that didn't work
  • Adopted Atlassian Confluence and Jira for knowledge and project mgmt
  • Adopted agile project mgmt, generally as described by Atlassian
  • Use Google Sheets to analyze distribution of tasks between team members, components, sprints, etc.
  • Key Take-Aways

About the speaker:

Erik is a Business Development Executive for the last 10+ years, responsible for partner ecosystems of up to $1B. With GreatAlbum, he's acting out a 20 year old dream to build a website/app that enables people to collaboratively build and share rich stories about the family and friends that inspire them! He is the Founder, leading a small development team.

Our lives are structured by the data we resource and how well we can understand it. From keeping track of books we all want to read, managing our finances, to planning team allocations for our projects. For all this there has been a long standing tool to help us manage and sort our data... spreadsheets.

In this session attendees will learn how to utilize spreadsheets (specifically Google Sheets) to almost magically organize, tabulate, process and analyze data for problems small and large.

Attendees will walk away understanding how to approach structuring data for a spreadsheet, how to use basic functions to transform/analyze data, manipulate data with complex features and format data for easy review.

More from the speaker:

Since 2013 I have presented 50 talks at 41 different conferences/camps, in 4 different countries. A full list of my recorded sessions can be viewed on my personal website at www.mike-miles.com/sessions.

Since 2016 I have been the host of the Developing Up podcast. A podcast focused on the non-technical side of being a developer. Each episode features me speaking with guest(s) about a non-technical topic that is related to career growth as a developer/engineer. Episodes are released on a monthly basis.

In addition, since 2015 I have been the lead organizer of the Boston Drupal Meetup Group, which meets monthly. As the lead organizer part of my duties include acting as the M.C. for each meetup.
You have the tech chops - now it's time to earn visibility and trust, with content!

This session is intended to provide tech specialists and NERD members who have excellent skills but are looking to expand their reputation and reach beyond their current contacts and database. We'll look at how that's done via an ongoing content strategy - designed to earn topic authority, trust - and eventually opt-in data and community around your specialty. I'd like to follow this up with a birds of a feather discussion the the next day if folks are interested. Though this would be a presentation, it would be an interactive session.

From the speaker:

I have expertise in B2B content strategy, some of that translates very well to content strategy for smaller businesses and tech solopreneurs....... I've done some workshops on that with Western Mass Podcamp that have gone very well. Basically the theme would be something like, "You have the tech chops, now how to you grow your business? Earn attention with content... (community, etc). I have defined a methodology around content strategy that encompasses lead gen but expands into the concept of building opt-in audiences. It also includes social media participation - and why it's crucial to develop topic authority and shareable content before getting heavily into social media for business.

I am is the co-founder of diginomica, an eight year old niche media company in the enterprise software arena. I am usually travelling too much to participate in NERD Summit - not this year! In Western Mass, I was a co-founder of Hidden Tech. We provided programming for techies and solopreneurs for 15 years. A lot of my pieces on content strategy are here www.bagtheweb.com/b/WsuzMZ.
Representatives from FIT Staffing will be available for one-on-one sessions with attendees to review their resumes and/or questions they have about interviewing. Please bring your resume with you.
Technical Resume Hacks: For When Recruiters Don't Know Their SaaS From Their Elbow

Learn how to grab the attention of recruiters and get them to understand the value you will add to their organization within just six seconds of looking at your resume with a unique approach to resume writing that hiring teams haven't seen before. Includes a dozen examples from entry level to VP!

* I listed the audience level as beginner, but it's really for any and all levels.

More from the speaker:

I have spoken at NERD Summit 2020, Women Who Code Boston, Women Who Code Portland, MentorWorks Education Capital, and BrightTalk.

Despite our best efforts, it's difficult to future proof a website for accessibility standards.

Your code and design may follow current standards, but will your careful compliance become obsolete when new guidelines are released? What happens when the site is updated or content is entered? What browsers or assistive technology agents do your consumers use?

We will review and demo a holistic approach for the complete lifecycle of an accessible website ‚Äîincluding how to iterate on existing content without impacting the hard work you put in during the build. Attendees will come away from this session with:

  • How to get started on improving accessibility on an existing site
  • Tips on what useful combinations of user agents, browsers, devices, etc. to test
  • A list of free tools that a site owner/content author can use to be sure their website is compliant before and after a build
  • What WCAG 2.2 guidelines are on the horizon

About the speaker:

AmyJune is an active contributor in the open-source world. As the Open Source Community Ambassador at Kanopi Studios, with a dual focus on both open-source community development and inclusivity, she is uniquely positioned to help individuals become more comfortable and confident as they contribute to their communities.

In her continued efforts to make a difference, she helps organize A11yTalks, an online meetup where they invite folks on every month to talk about all things accessibility - one of the core components of building an inclusive web.

In addition to her work building community connections, AmyJune is an avid geocacher, noted Volkswagen enthusiast, and eats with her elbows on the table.
Turning stress into assurance: Continuity planning during times of uncertainty

We've been immersed in this global pandemic for upwards 9 months. We've spent weeks sheltered-in-place, with limited in-person interaction. While change is a norm in today's workplace, the global pandemic has layered on a new challenge of uncertainty. It's caused an increase in fear, anxiety, and stress. For this unique moment of repose and uncertainty we are living in, continuity planning has never been more important.

About the speaker:

Meghan Davis is a Senior Project Manager and Team Lead with Palantir.net. Based out of Cape Cod, Massachusetts, Meghan manages complex digital projects and portfolios across many industries, most notably government (from local to state to federal) and healthcare, as well as education and non-profit. Meghan is responsible for leading cross-functional teams of strategists, designers, and developers using agile and lean methodologies to deliver value to our clients and help them achieve their business goals. Additionally, Meghan leads the development of project management best practices, with a particular focus on risk management and mitigation, continuity planning, and retrospectives.

Blog post: Turning Stress into Assurance: Continuity Planning During Times of Uncertainty

Blog post: Becoming a More Collaborative Teammate Through Internal Reflection

Blog post: Facilitating Goal-Driven Retrospectives to Build Your Team's Growth Mindset

Drupal.org user name: meghandavis

Cool stuff in Python 3 you might not be using

Python 3 lived for so long in the shadow of Python 2 that a lot of developers missed learning about cool new features. Handy things like the "walrus operator" and "f-strings"; improvements to the type system that make it harder to write bugs; and new tools like "asyncio" for concurrent programming. Come survey the cool stuff with me and come away with tools for writing better Python!

About the speaker:

Paul Bissex (he/him) is a web application engineer specializing in Python and Django (though he likes Haskell, Clojure, and Rust too). He co-wrote "Python Web Development with Django", one of the first Django books.

He's worked for ten-person startups and 8,000-person megacorps. He currently is Principal Software Engineer for MassChallenge, a global startup accelerator headquartered in Boston.

He also runs dpaste.com, a programmer pastebin site used by the Django and iPython projects.

He's been happily leading sessions at NERD Summit for many years, in addition to other venues like the Boston Django Meetup.
How building an Alexa app for Imposter Syndrome Helped beat my imposter syndrome.

An overview of Impostor Syndrome how common it is in women in tech and what can be done about it. An overview of how to create an AWS Alexa Voice activated App using easy blueprints and a backend serverless lambda.

From the speaker:

I am a programmer working for Liberty Mutual recently pivoted to programming and wish to encourage more women in tech and share my experience of Imposter Syndrome in the hope to help others and also share how easy it is to create an Alexa app. I am an AWS certified developer / a comp science degree from 20 years ago / a recent boot camper and a tech enthusiast. I have 4 children and have relocated to the states from Ireland.

How to talk so leaders will listen

"Have you ever had a problem to solve? One where you and your team finally landed on some possible solutions and when you went to share your epiphany, the leader or stakeholder didn't listen?

Sometimes, no matter the effort and creativity expended, leaders just don't listen. Why is influencing so difficult?

This scenario happens regularly and we want to discuss options, alternatives and share ideas on what works."

Anyone who's worked in a small business knows how central the customer is to its success. As an organization grows larger, so do its needs for structural stability, yet customer centricity becomes no less important. Let's discuss this topic, including questions such as:

  1. How do we grow and stay stable as an organization while retaining our ability to nimbly adapt as our customers' needs change over time?
  2. Why do hierarchies slow down decision-making and how can we speed it up?
  3. How can leverage our successful organizational agility at scale?

More from the moderator

My primary passion and motivation is in delivering better products by getting production teams and customers closer together through automation and empathy. I aspire to apply my skills and past successes in leadership strategy and management innovation to larger and larger organizations.
Your developer journey; how did you get here?

This BoF will be a discussion around your journey with software development, including how you discovered and started doing it, how you learned, how you continue to educate yourself about it, and how it has changed for you over the years.

Discussion questions:

  1. When did you first start in software development and how did that happen?
  2. How did you learn, and how do you continue to educate yourselves today?
  3. How has development changed for you since you first started doing it and has that been positive or negative?

We will spend roughly 15 minutes on each question. Please try to limit your answers to 2-3 minutes to allow roughly 5-8 people to speak on each question.

About the moderator:

Freelance graphic design and web dev since 2000. Prior to that, managed a boatbuilding and service operation near Newport, RI. Now full time web dev at Common Media, Inc. commonmedia.com since 2011.

...also Yacht Insider's Guide since 2009 www.yachtinsidersguide.com

...and music as a hobby soundcloud.com/flowte

The team at FIT Staffing will cover an overview of Jobs in the Valley, specific to Developers. We will also cover updated Salary data for tech jobs in the local area and how they compare to other areas of the country.

KEYNOTE:  Anna Hall - Purpose is Your Superpower!

This presentation will help all attendees, regardless of coding ability or experience, to understand the power of purpose. The goal is to inspire excitement and build confidence by sharing evidence-based practices that can can spark joy and meaning. Knowing one's purpose empowers perseverance, motivation and confidence that can carry each of us through the inevitable challenges in life and career.

Purpose is so much more than a great idea or a cause you value. Purpose is the force that powers us through disappointments, heartaches, failures, and funding challenges. It fortifies good health, wellbeing and longevity. My curiosity about its impact was piqued by people living with Alzheimer’s disease. I observed that even cognitive decline doesn’t affect the human spirit’s need for meaning. Learn how to identify your unique purpose and harness the internal energy that sustains excitement and determination in all realms of your life

Many of us have been doing this for a long time now. The rest of the world was force to join us this year. What have we learned? What has changed? What will go back to the old "normal"? What is the new normal?

More from the moderator

My primary passion and motivation is in delivering better products by getting production teams and customers closer together through automation and empathy. I aspire to apply my skills and past successes in leadership strategy and management innovation to larger and larger organizations.

"There are a number of services the allow teams to develop continuous integration & delivery (CI/CD) pipelines for their online Projects. CI/CD can help with running automated regression testing, static code analysis, even code deployment. It would be great to have a conversation with others to learn what services they are using, how they are using them and how it helps your project / team.

3 Discussion Questions:

  1. What service are you using for CI/CD on your project?
  2. How has using a CI/CD pipeline improved your project and team capabilities?
  3. From a high-level what is your CI/CD pipeline/workflow and where are you looking to improve?"

More from the speaker:

Since 2013 I have presented 50 talks at 41 different conferences/camps, in 4 different countries. A full list of my recorded sessions can be viewed on my personal website at www.mike-miles.com/sessions.

Since 2016 I have been the host of the Developing Up podcast. A podcast focused on the non-technical side of being a developer. Each episode features me speaking with guest(s) about a non-technical topic that is related to career growth as a developer/engineer. Episodes are released on a monthly basis.

In addition, since 2015 I have been the lead organizer of the Boston Drupal Meetup Group, which meets monthly. As the lead organizer part of my duties include acting as the M.C. for each meetup.
BoF Workshop - You have the tech chops #2 - now it's time to earn visibility and trust, with content!

This is a workshop version of the Friday session on content strategy and earning visibility and trust with potential clients (and plugging into community around them). You don't have to attend the Friday session to attend the workshop. The workshop will bring more interactive opportunities for each participant to share their challenges around creating a sustainable content strategy and building a client network around that. Jon Reed will also walk you through the steps in his content strategy and we can hit on whatever steps people are stuck in - from finding your authentic voice to social media engagement to opt-in emails.

From the moderator:

I have expertise in B2B content strategy, some of that translates very well to content strategy for smaller businesses and tech solopreneurs....... I've done some workshops on that with Western Mass Podcamp that have gone very well. Basically the theme would be something like, "You have the tech chops, now how to you grow your business? Earn attention with content... (community, etc). I have defined a methodology around content strategy that encompasses lead gen but expands into the concept of building opt-in audiences. It also includes social media participation - and why it's crucial to develop topic authority and shareable content before getting heavily into social media for business.

I am is the co-founder of diginomica, an eight year old niche media company in the enterprise software arena. I am usually travelling too much to participate in NERD Summit - not this year! In Western Mass, I was a co-founder of Hidden Tech. We provided programming for techies and solopreneurs for 15 years. A lot of my pieces on content strategy are here www.bagtheweb.com/b/WsuzMZ.

Agile Product/Project Mgmt for Distributed Team

This BOF session will be a follow-on from the presentation session on Friday. It's open to anyone who wants to dig deeper into how to do product mgmt of your app/website and how to implement product requirements in agile project mgmt.

About the moderator:

Erik is a Business Development Executive for the last 10+ years, responsible for partner ecosystems of up to $1B. With GreatAlbum, he's acting out a 20 year old dream to build a website/app that enables people to collaboratively build and share rich stories about the family and friends that inspire them! He is the Founder, leading a small development team.
Let’s discuss a recent State of DevOps report and why organizations struggle with adoption.

What is Mob Programming?

Mob Programing multiple brilliant minds focused on solving a single issue. How much does it cost for 5 developers to spend 10 minutes solving a problem that would take a single developer 5 hours to solve?

However with more voices in the room you can either create more noise or more production, how do you optimize your developers experience and create safety for all brain and personality types? How do you balance out the ability to solve a logical problem vs the ability to program the solution in a given language? Mob programming balances these things out.

2. What is a Code Koans?

A code Koans is a way of practicing a language. IT is a library of broken tests that one goes through and make pass. It teaches a language from a Test Driven approach in baby steps. In this session we will use a Code Koans to learn and practice how to:

  • Talk to each other with respect.
  • Solve a problem in a constructive manner.
  • share information for faster and more rapid development experience.
  • Listen to everyone.

I have been using Mob programming since 2015 to solve problems faster, level up team members and just build better working relationships. It's not for everybody but everybody should try it.

This session is open to everyone and will change developers in any part of technological journey, while being accessible to beginners. I would encourage people who feel both programmatically and management inclined to take part.

More from the moderator:

Myself and NERDS go way back. I have been on the selection committee (either DruaplCamp or NERDS I can't recall) before. As well as was one of the first Presenters ever at a NERD summit.

I am an ex web application developer who has spent the Last 7-8 years more in DevOps and reliability engineering. However I have had to taken the past few years off presenting as I have been morphing and growing my abilities and focus.

I have given this presentation a few times for different audiences and have slides ready at https://koans-deck-josh-beauregard.herokuapp.com/ (hit s as soon as it loads for speaker notes) IT will obviously need tweaking for a filly remote setting.
